productDescription: The KitchenAid Blade Coffee Grinder makes quick and simple work of grinding beans for up to 12 cups of coffee.
Markings on the inside of the stainless steel bowl indicate suitable bean levels for 4, 8, 10 or 12 cups of brewed coffee, and the clear top cover slides on for one-touch operation.
Allows for operation at the touch of a buttonsimply push down on the cover to begin grinding and release to stop. The clear cover also allows you to easily see the consistency of grinds.
Offers durability and powerful performance, quickly grinding enough whole coffee beans to make up to 12 cups of coffee.

Features measurement markings on the inside, so you know at a glace the quantity of coffee beans needed to make 4, 8, 10 or 12 cups of coffee. The bowl lifts out, making it easy to transfer grinds to the coffee maker.
Stainless steel spice grinding bowls with spice optimized blade design, for spices such as coriander and cumin. Included with Model BCG211 or can be purchased separately (Part: BCGSGA).
Heavy duty motor housing, stainless steel 4-ounce capacity bowl with stainless steel coffee grinder blade, clear top cover.
Heavy duty motor housing, stainless steel 4-ounce capacity bowl with stainless steel coffee grinder blade, clear top cover, spice grinder accessory kit.

2 removable grinding bowls to eliminate cross contamination. These grinding bowls have measurement markings and are dishwasher safe. This kit also includes 2 storage lids and 1 shake and sprinkle lid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very happy... wait a second... {sip} {sip} ahhh
reviews.reviewText:
I waited a couple months to write this as there was so much conflicting information in the reviews that I wanted to have an experienced opinion.

None of the complaints were correct... it works perfectly, I gave it 4 stars as its a basic model and doesn't have advanced setting like grin level etc, but if you just want to grind your own beans for fresh coffee its great. Simple and easy.

I actually just made myself a fresh cup of coffee before sitting down... hold on... {sip} ahhhh,,, that's the stuff.

One review complained about coffee getting stuck under the blade, and while coffee can get stuck if you over grind by grinding too long or put in too many beans (I usually grind about half a cup of beans at a time), I quickly found that I only had to grind for 10 seconds to get the grind I needed. I suspect the complainer was over-grinding or filling the grinder passed the recommended max bean level. And even when it sticks a little to the bottom (I over grinded the second time I used it and it stuck a little), I have a separate container I use to store a few days worth of ground beans and I turn the removable grind cup upside down and tap it into my container. Its not that hard, and you can easily spin the blade with a knife to loosen any stuck coffee if you overdid it. Hardly an issue, and I would expect all grinders have to be handled in the same manner.

We recently purchased this coffee grinder for grinding Not Coffee in our lab area. Obviously, this isn't the intended use case, but it seems to work quite well for this purpose. However, when you are grinding anything in the metal container, the plastic part doesn't really properly seal to the cup, and so coffee (or Not Coffee) tends to spill out the sides and into the crevices between the bottom mount and the metal cup, which can be quite a mess and hard to clean. Luckily, a simple fix that we implemented was to place a small O-ring around the top of the coffee grinder to kind of seal the cup, or at least minimize particulate flow out of the cup and into the surrounding area. The O-ring we purchased (it is very cheap on McMaster, though I'm sure there are even cheaper sources) was 3in ID and 3.125in OD (see picture for specific part number) and fits very snugly into the top of the grinder. Now it works quite well without spilling Not Coffee (or coffee) into the side. Hurray!

reviews.reviewTitle: Ok if you're only using it for coffee, I guess
reviews.reviewText:
If your intent is to grind your daily Joe this one will work just fine. It packs a punch, strong enough to grind dried cinnamon sticks to dust in almost no time. It has even tackled hard-as-a-rock dried ginseng root with determination. But I am using it to grind herbs, and there are drawbacks.

1. The lid does not fit tightly against the canister. When doing long grinds for harder herbs a lot of dust accumulates between the lid and the canister, and even escapes. When small amounts of herbs are weighed before grinding this translates to an unacceptable loss, throwing off formulas.

2. There are gaps in the construction which allow herb dust to lodge itself into cracks and crevices, making it difficult to get out. I usually have to hit it with a paint brush to sweep it out.

3. I recently threw some sugar into the grinder to powder it. The white sugar "liberated" a large accumulation of darker herbs that had been lodged under the grinding blade. Not knowing what I had in there, I had to throw away 1/4 cup of sugar and start again.

I suppose if I were only using it for coffee these drawbacks would be fine--coffee doesn't need a long grind time, and if you're not using it for anything else then perhaps it's ok to have debris left in the mechanism, assuming it would rotate through and be relatively fresh. But this is not a good choice for an herbalist or for a cook who wants to grind their kitchen herbs.

reviews.reviewTitle: It creates a nice uniform grinds and I'm very happy with it
reviews.reviewText:
I got this to replace a Cuisinart grinder that I had for years. At first I didn't care for the KitchenAid's round shape, but after using it for a month now, it's very well built and quieter than the Cuisinart.

It creates a nice uniform grinds and I'm very happy with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works perfectly! Also easy clean-up with a few tips!
reviews.reviewText:
Despite my worry over the very polarized love/hate reviews... I am so glad I purchased this unit. It works perfectly for my needs and is a breeze to use and clean up.

Background: I just got a cold brew system (Love, love, love it, here it is if you think you might love smooth, lower-acid cold brew, too:OXO Good Grips Cold Brew Coffee Makerand I needed a grinder since none of my local shops - unless I went to Starbucks exclusively - had one in-store, I had to get one for myself. I looked around, read reviews and settled on this one. I love it and I am actually glad I didn't have the option to settle for grinding in the store! I can use this little guy to make it *just so* and that's awesome!

My thoughts after using it for awhile:

- So easy to use! Drop your beans in the cup, replace lid and press down to grind! So simple!

- You can also easily adjust according to your needs. But for my needs (of very coarse ground coffee for my cold brew system) I fill the cup to the 10-12 line (see images I attached) and I press 8 times, for a fraction of a second, counting 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8! I gently wiggle the unit in my hand, look at the beans and then do the process again, counting to about 5 or 8 depending on how the grind looks at the pause point. More additional grinds are needed for when the beans are less ground up, less when they are more ground up. This makes roughly a cup of coarse grind.

- I have been playing around with different beans and I have found the bean can radically change how it grinds. Very oily beans tend to take a little more grinding and wiggling. They also get stuck in the bottom but I can dislodge them gently with a couple pokes of a spoon and then they fall right out. Oily beans tend not to be as messy outside the grinding cup. Drier beans grind faster and easier. They don't stick in the cup, but they can have little bits that fly into the top. If you remove the lid - with bean bits on it - to look at the beans in the cup (you don't need to to this btw - the lid is clear!) and then replace the lid you are very much more likely to get some bits in the bottom under the cup. I noticed this and I don't remove the lid and put it back on with bits on it anymore. As an aside - the pressure of putting the lid on after removing it could also cause bean bits to fly up and out of the cup. Just don't remove the lid until you are done grinding! EASY FIX to keep CLEAN UP EASY! :-)

- When I am done grinding, I immediately rinse the cup and the lid, and set it out to dry. I feel like hand washing when you can - especially when things don't get really dirty - is the way to go to keep things nice longer. Especially plastic which could get brittle over time from Dishwasher heat settings. So far all I've had to do is blow out literally a couple flakes from the under the cup area. Then I've wiped out the interior (and the exterior of the main unit) with a hot, wet cloth, or a disinfecting wipe periodically. Easy peasy!

Bottom line: This thing is so easy to use, works great and is easy to clean. It's not too big and it was a decent price for how well it works, how sturdy it feels, how much I've used it so far and it's aforementioned attributes. Highly suggest you give this baby a try if you need your own grinder, and especially if you are looking into cold brewing! I am not a coffee snob by any means, but cold brew is so yummy you should give it a try! Particularly if you ever find regular coffee too acidic. :-)

Hope this review helps, but if you have comments, questions or suggestions - leave a comment! I try to reply as soon as possible. :-)

UPDATE 02/05/2019: Still going strong about a year and a half later. Looks and works like new. No complaints. Would buy again or recommend to anyone who wants to grind their own beans. Thanks!

I purchased this grinder as a spice grinder. SO far I've used it twice: once to grind instant tapioca pearls, and once to grind caraway seeds. I both cases, I was grinding an amount less than 3 tablespoons. In both cases, an unacceptable amount of what powder there was flew out of the metal grinding container and into the plastic workings surrounding it. Unacceptable. In both cases, but especially with the caraway seeds, and despite grinding for several 25-second intervals, the result was nowhere near "ground" - finely chopped, maybe, but not ground. Unacceptable. Perhaps this thing works better with coffee beans, but I can't imagine it. Waste of money. For a few dollars more, I could have gotten something that actually works. I'd return it, but Amazon's shipping label policy makes this more trouble than it's worth for me.

Pretty, shiny, Kitchen-Aid. We were so hopeful! It was so terrible. It didn't work as well as the one we had for 10 years even right out of the package, but we were willing to give it a try just because it was pretty. But after two weeks, it has stopped working completely. We can't get it to turn on when we press down at all. We have cleaned it, adjusted every possible thing in it, taken the cup out (and it works with the cup removed), cleaned the cup and wiped the gears....and nothing. Don't waste your money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice grinder, but will eventually break
reviews.reviewText:
We bought this grinder from Amazon in March of 2014, so it just went out of warranty. It worked fine pretty much most of the time. We had a Krups before this, and would have kept using it but had water damage and had to be thrown away. It worked for years without incident, but was a hassle since its grinding cup couldn't be removed. The KitchenAid grinder was better in that you weren't dragging a power cord over your canister where the coffee would go. Even so, my wife wasn't as happy with the way this new grinder seemed to not grind the beans as evenly as the Krups once did. It was a small complaint, and we continued using it.

Today I went to empty the stainless cup, and it wouldn't twist off as normal. I didn't force it, I tried wiggling it a little while trying to twist it. That didn't work, so I carefully laid the grinder on its side and the cup finally came off. I then realized the problem was that a large piece of plastic was preventing the cup from being removed. It was part of the bottom of the cup that interlocks into the motor unit, to hold it in place while grinding. It's just out of warranty, so I tried to simply buy a new cup for it. I figured that would be easy. Not the case. I've been all over the net and can't find the part. I've been on all the sites, so I don't believe they are selling it. This would mean having to buy a whole new unit for the sake of the one part that is most likely to break and takes all of the "abuse."

The plastic at the bottom that interlocks to the motor shaft has a thin area, and that's where it broke. The plastic itself is quite brittle and reminds me of the older appliances that used Bakelite parts, although I'm sure that's not what it's made of. In short, I can't recommend this grinder since if you can't even buy the one most important and obvious part for it, then the whole thing is worthless. Everything else on it is like new. I've also noted others have had the same problem with this model. I've included a picture. You can see that this hasn't been abused, scraped, bent, mishandled or not used according to the manual. It just broke. I would venture to say that eventually it will happen to yours as well. KitchenAid could diffuse the whole problem by simply offering this part on their website for a reasonable price. The fact that it's not there is ridiculous. KitchenAid has been a trademark for tough reliable products for years, so we purchased the grinder with that in mind. We once owned a KitchenAid dishwasher which was built like a tank. Sadly, I believe they've resorted to making their products overseas like all the other U.S. companies have. Once that happens, then there is no way of knowing what the component parts are really made of.

I grew up in San Francisco and lived in Seattle for a long time. In other words, I like good coffee! I know that there are coffee purists who will pooh pooh anything but a burr grinder, but frankly I can't tell the difference between a burr grinder and this one. I had a Cuisinart DCG-12BC that died after a year. Bought another one. Died. Enough of the Cuisinart brand. So I replaced it with this. And I'm super happy with it. It looks nice, but more importantly it does an excellent job of grinding coffee and doesn't spill everywhere when you dump out the grounds, which the Krups F203 does every single time. I've had mine a year, and it seems to be going strong. I'm buying another one for our other house.

This grinder received one star for the fact that it looks nice and seems pretty durable. However, when it comes to actually using the grinder, it is horrible!! Youre supposed to just secure the lid and press down however 9 times out of 10 when you press down nothing happens. I usually have to fight with the thing for 5 to 10 minutes to finally get it to grind. Its super frustrating and very inconvenient. I gave this to my husband for a Christmas present and almost two months later I am witting this review. I gave it some time to see if we just needed to get used to how it worked and we have both tried numerous ways to press down and there is no rhyme or reason on when we can finally get it to grind. We are highly disappointed. Dont waste your money!

reviews.reviewTitle: WTH? Instructions claim not recommended for expresso machines ...
reviews.reviewText:
I ordered this along with an expresso machine. Both items came today. No where in this product's item description does it list it shouldn't be purchased to grind beans for expresso machines. However, when I read this grinder's instructions it states on page 8: "KitchenAid does not recommend using this grinder to grind beans for pump espresso-type machines."
Apparently it is only supposed to be used for automatic drip and French press (which uses a coarse grind). Likely because also on page 8, it also states..."Longer grinding times result in finer grinds but can overheat the coffee grinds and valuable coffee flavors can be lost."

The product description should clearly state it is recommended for automatic drip and French press coffee machines only!

Very disappointing! Sure it is nice to look at but its grinding capability is very poor. I think this is due to the depth of the basket and the weaker motor or a combination thereof. I like to grind my coffee very fine - a near powder consistency. This grinder seems unable to do this even at half capacity. A portion of beans are ground finely then stick to the bottom, while most of the beans above it are ground coarsely. I've had to dump out the coarsely ground beans, then scrape out the powdery grounds off the bottom of the canister then put the coarser grind back in for round two. Most definitely NOT the grinder for morning coffeeholics (me) who are need of a quick fix as soon as they get up! I'll be getting another grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: I still dislike this very much
reviews.reviewText:
Grind bits all over. This is very messy grinder, I tried to get used to it, but after nearly 1 year, I still dislike this very much.
It takes much longer to grind compare to my 10years old hamilton beach grinder. when you shake to get even inside, bits of coffee grind pour over and get underneath grinder and cover. Everymorning I use this, I have to clean the counter and takes more time for me to clean than actually grinding with this things. Kitchin Aid, I really doubt you did testing before this is delivered to customer. This is one of the WORST grinder.

I followed the directions carefully and even did some experimenting, and just could not get a consistent grind...too much dust collects under the blade, and too many large particles above it, it's never consistent. I know many people may not care too much and just want their coffee ground for a coffee maker, but I'm using a pour over with a permanent filter, and the bottom of my cup is full of silt when I use this grinder, not to mention that silt causes a bitter flavor. I think the choice here is either to stick to consistent pre ground coffee, or buy a quality (expensive) burr grinder- by most accounts, the cheaper burr grinders won't be better than this one and may actually be worse.

reviews.reviewTitle: This grinder seems to have been designed by King Kong
reviews.reviewText: This grinder seems to have been designed by King Kong. I don't have particularly small hands, and find that I can't get my hand around this to pick it up. And speaking of picking up, this is one heavy coffee grinder. Also, I can grind a scoop of coffee beans for 1 minute and still not get a fine grind. I used this about 6 times, then put it into the garage sale box. Somebody else can wrestle with it. I bought a krups grinder. At least I know that I can pick it up with one hand and get a fine grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: A solid product from KitchenAid with an excellent price ($20)
reviews.reviewText: I have only had this for a few weeks but I am very impressed with the quality. The product is very solid with a stainless steel bowl and blades. The top is made of heavy clear acrylic to view grind consistency. The stainless bowl locks in the base with a 1/4 turn. There are graduations on the bowl for 4,8,10 or 12 cups. The bowl and top are dishwasher safe. Dimensions are H: 8 3/4 W: 3 5/16, D; 4 1/4. With a 160 watt motor it has no problem grinding a full bowl of beans. As with my other KA products I expect to get years of service from this unit. For $20 this is a great buy. So far I have no complaints with this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to use, makes a mess
reviews.reviewText:
I hate this product for the following reasons:

1) It doesn't grind my coffee finely at all. There are always big chunks left. This was not the case with the small cheap proctor silex grinder I used to own. It's also super difficult to judge when to stop holding down the lid to stop grinding.

2) The grinds get everywhere. Including the space between the canister and motor, which makes it difficult to screw the canister in and out, which you need to do every time you use it! It's really hard to get the grinds out from the base, I've had to use a paintbrush for this purpose!

3) You have to use a fair amount of force and leverage just to push down on the lid to make the grinder go. This isn't exactly a huge problem, but an annoyance for a device you use every day.

This is just such a poorly designed product, I don't comprehend why it has good reviews from others. When I reached out to KitchenAid about these issues a month after receiving the item, they basically just said that I could return it if it was within the return window (30 days), which it was not. Don't make the same mistake as me!

It appears to be a good design with the ability to remove the grinding cup however a significant amount of grounds is already collecting under the cup. Im assuming this will eventually make fitting the cup in place difficult. Ive hardly had it a few weeks and have already wrestled with a basting brush to get the area under the cup clean. Its also very loud and tinny sounding. Im sending it back. Its a shame they dont make things like they used to. Ill go back to using my ten year Old grinder with a broken cover.??

It runs fine, but I bought it to grind spices and it doesn't work the greatest for it. First, the top of the cup doesn't touch the top of the plastic lid, so ground spice dust flies everywhere out of the cup making it a mess when you take the lid off. As someone else mentioned, it does show problems grinding up evenly. I tried to grind some dried mushrooms and the dust flew everywhere and there were plenty of chunks that I needed to pick out to regrind. I assume this would work best for coffee beans because of their weight as long as you fill the cup. I did cut a square out of a ziploc bag and place it over the top of the cup and then secure it with a rubber band; this helped significantly with the dust issue. I would not buy it again and would not recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for the price and did buy again after a year
reviews.reviewText: My husband bought me one of these last year as well as a French press and I really like it so I bought my mother one this year. It is easy to use and easy to get the desired fineness depending on if you are using a press or pot. My only minor issue is that the bowl or whatever it is called is easy to take off and clean but the machine itself is not really that easy to clean, but it is great for the price. Obviously I would buy again and for my mother.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to get anything but a very fine grind
reviews.reviewText: It's hard to get anything but a very fine grind - which is great, if that's what you want. But because we use a screen filter instead of paper in our coffee maker, we like a medium coarse grind that prevents a lot of sediment from coming through. Unfortunately, in this grinder the whole beans seem to float on top while the grounds at the bottom get finer and finer. By the time all the beans are ground, it's like cake flour. My cheap old Mr. Coffee grinder made it easier to control the grind. Just a quick shake during the grind would drop the whole beans to the bottom until I could get a nice medium grind throughout. Because of the way the clear dome fits over the grinding reservoir, I can't do that with this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: The inner bowl does snap in and twist out with no issues like some others on the market
reviews.reviewText: The KitchenAid BCG111OB does work well and does perform as advertised. The inner bowl does snap in and twist out with no issues like some others on the market. The bowl is thin and if you don't pay attention it can be sharp. It does grind coffee pretty evenly, unless you are only grinding about four (4) cups. Apparently it was not designed to grind only four cups worth of beans. Nonetheless, If we ever need to purchase another coffee bean grinder, for the price we paid, we would purchase this KitchenAid BCG111OB grinder again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very messy and does not grind evenly
reviews.reviewText: This is the messiest coffee grinder, I am very disappointed in it. As I grind the beans the grinds get between the metal container and the base (there seems to be a way for them to escape where the blades are). Also, the beans do not get ground thoroughly and evenly. Some are left in chunks. I am not happy with this coffee grinder.

I purchased the onyx black grinder to use at work. It's so wonderful having a pot of freshly ground coffee everyday. The grinder itself it a breeze to use and even easier to clean. On the inside of the stainless steel cup (where the grinder blades are located), it has markings to indicate how much whole beans you need to make 4,6,8,10 and 12 cups of coffee. For the couple times I've used it, the markings have been pretty accurate for me (I use 1 tablespoon of finely ground coffee per two cups of water). When you're ready to clean your cup, all you do is twist it slightly and pull it out. Then I quickly rinse it out and place it in our drying rack, along with the rinsed out lid. Too easy! Overall, a really great product that I would recommend to others! I see myself getting many years use out of this product, but that is what you would expect from the Kitchen Aid brand!

I store my whole coffee beans in anOXO Good Grips POP Big Square 2.4-Quart Storage Container; it does a great job of keeping my beans fresh!

Came as advertised, on time, clean, noise as expected, easy to clean and with clear directions etc... no problems there. And it's compact which I wanted so to save counter space.
Issue 1: Top of the SS bean cup is not sharp enough to cut your hand when cleaning etc... however its thin metal which makes you very aware you could as you'll need to press and turn it with a good amount of force. There should be some kind of cap such as silicon or rubber or the top rolled over on itself around the top. Issue 2: Most important I found that the grounds are not as uniform as I had hoped. For instance when fine grinding at the manufactures recommended times 10% (estimate) come out a little less than 1/8" in size. Grinding longer and shaking to mix them up doesn't seem to make much difference. I used a "BURR" at my sons place, it's larger in size but grinds come out perfect with no shaking etc...

reviews.reviewTitle: Look no further, you have found your grinder!
reviews.reviewText: Love the grinder! My fiance and I are baristas so coffee is a BIG deal in this household. We love the grind and while loud(shocking a loud grinder?!) the sound does not travel. We can grind coffee in the kitchen of our apartment and barely hear it in the bedroom, our neighbors appreciate this feature at 3am. My only complaint is that the grounds get really packed into the bottom so sometimes you have to mix it up to grind everything evenly. The grinder can do up to 12 cups I believe, but I stay around 8 to get a good grind. Looks nice, so if it gets left out on the counter it is not an eye sore at all! But, do not worry about having to find space for it! Small and easy to put in any cabinet!

I bought this to replace an old Mr. Coffee grinder that I used for grinding peppercorns and making my own spice blends. I don't have a problem with the job it does grinding, but when you remove the top, there is finely ground spice all over the lip that the cap rests on, and when you remove the bowl, now there is ground spice under the bowl where the piece that makes the blade spin is, which is difficult to clean. I did not have this problem with my old grinder. I regret not returning it now. Edit: I returned it and ordered a Krups, which is almost identical in size and design as my old Mr. Coffee and does an excellent job, so I'm happy now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Faulty design: Grind your beans and clean your kitchen!
reviews.reviewText:
I know KitchenAid as one of the top brands on the market and expected a device with a clever design.
The grinder looks nice and appears very sturdy, but the beans don't stay in the metal pot. There is a gap of a few millimeters between the metal pot and the cap that cannot be closed by pressing on the lid. Once you grind the beans they will jump in the metal pot and of course through the gap. The finer you grind the more jumps out and collects on the outer rim. Once you remove the lid all this stuff falls on your kitchen table. I watched the video of this ad twice to check whether an o-ring or a gasket was missing, but no ... this is a flaw in the design that could have been fixed easily.
There are much better grinders for the same price available that don't mess up your kitchen.
Now I have to buy a pack of 50-100 o-rings (as suggested by another reviewer) for approx. 50% of the price of the grinder. Notably, not each o-ring can be used for food purpose (CA proposition 65 - exposure to chemicals that can cause cancer)... But for this grinder, this probably doesn't matter a lot, since it comes with a CA proposition 65 anyway.
I recommend not buying it! There are better grinders!
Pictures attached.

reviews.reviewTitle: good grind but not worth it
reviews.reviewText: I was surprised cuz this was one of the highest rated grinders. I wish I would have purchased a different one. The grinder is activate by pushing down on the cap. but its a bad design because you can feel sometimes when you push down it does not align properly and nothing happens so you have to pull it off and re-seat the lid. Also, you cannot shake this grinder as grounds will go up and over the inside causing a large mess on the counter when you remove the lid.

I bought this grinder because one of the blades broke off my old grinder ($10 Cuisinart from the grocery store), so it was running at half efficiency and it was pretty loud. Well, you'd think this more powerful Kitchen Aid grinder with two intact blades and great reviews would work better, but it doesn't.

It takes twice as long to grind my coffee to a medium size and there's still big chunks in it. There's also fine coffee grounds that get stuck underneath the blades, so you have to scrape them off. It also doesn't grind if you're holding it in your hands--grinding at an angle helps prevent some of that coffee that gets stuck at the bottom, but I can't even do that. I am disappointed.

This coffee grinder is a welcome addition to my KitchenAid appliance kitchen. It performs as good or better than other counterparts while maintaining the KitchenAid build quality and aesthetics. I use this coffee grinder almost daily to prepare my morning coffee. It requires minimal cleaning and always performs to the highest standard.

For kitchen items, there are only a handful brands I pick. KitchenAid is one of such brands. It represents quality.
And their products are generally well-made.
This coffee grinder is substantial in weight, unlike those light-weighted units.
A major feature that I like is the removal of the grinding bowl. The last unit that I had did not have this feature, which made cleaning a little awkward.

One feature (which I initially deemed was an issue) is the material of the removal bowl: its inside surface is not very smooth to touch. It appears and feels like it is made of aluminum, a metal I don't like. Just checked the product description on Amazon, the bowl is indeed stainless steel. Although the inside feels slightly rough to touch, the outside is smooth. I imagine this is a deliberate design to make the inside rough, thus creating some degree of resistance to stop the materials being grounded from just twirling around inside the bowl.

As usual, Im glad I picked this brand. Highly recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: doesn't grind all beans if you're doing a lot at a time
reviews.reviewText:
I had such high hopes for this grinder. Read quite a few reviews and it seemed like it would be grand. However, we grind a full measure of the beans (never exceeding what is indicated on the markings) and still need to grind more to make a single pot of really good coffee. That said, I've had to resort to doing multiple small batches as the beans don't all grind if you're trying to do a large quantity.
Also, there is an excess of coffee grinds jammed below the blade which must be knocked out, then the clumps broken up.
All in all, my old Cuisinart did a better job of grinding, though didn't have the removable bowl which is about the best feature on this unit.

I wonder if the designers of this coffee grinder actually used it to grind beans, because the unholy mess this thing makes is RIDIC. The design is terrible. It's a three-piece machine:
* Base/Engine
* Cup/bean holder/blade
* Cover/grinder-lever

You put the beans in the cup, fit the cup into the base, put the top on then push down to start grinding. Simple enough. The problem is that the top of the cup doesn't reach to the top of the cover. So when you grind your beans the grounds come over the top of the cup and spill everywhere. The second you take off the top your counter is covered in coffee, and what doesn't make it on to the counter falls into the base.

Oh, but now it's time to take the cup out of the base so you can pour the grounds into your French press! Go ahead. TRY and get the beans out. They're so tightly compacted into the bottom of the cup underneath the blade that you need a knife to get them out.

Do you get an even grind? No.

Am I satisfied? No.

It's a KITCHENAID! Come on, man. They can do so much better.

Great looking coffee grinder with a detachable grinder cup. After grinding the coffee I just lift the cup and pour the grounds into the coffee maker. With the old grinder, I had to unplug the unit and tip the whole thing to get grounds out and into the coffee maker.
The noise level is slightly less than the old traditional cylinder model.
The grinder delivers coarse grounds perfect for a drip coffee maker. If you want espresso grounds, look elsewhere.

I really wanted to like this, mostly because the cup comes off for cleaning. The problem is that if I put in more than tone-quarter cup of beans it will grind the ones at the bottom much more finely than the ones at the top, and then the bottom grounds get stuck under the blade so that the top ones don't get ground to the same fineness..
I was also hoping that it would be able to grind hard cheese as all my previous grinders had, but no such luck. Not only didn't it do much grinding but little pieces of cheese flew out during the process.
My local thrift store had a Barista blade coffee grinder or $8.00. I'd never heard of them, but it works like a charm. Heavy duty, does a great job with Parmesan cheese too.

It is a beautiful appliance and built from high quality materials. The clear top is a great design function. My beef with this grinder, however, is that it grinds the beans unevenly by a fairly considerable margin. It is hard to describe, but at the bottom of the container, beneath the blade, will be a collection of superfine coffee grounds compacted and "stuck" to the bottom; you will have to bang the bottom to get them out (and even sometimes that is not enough). On top of those grounds will then be a blend of medium to course grounds, with the occasional whole bean still floating around. It is more a nuisance than a dealbreaker, but this sort of thing will bother you, consider a burr grinder.

I purchased this to upgrade our old grinder. Though it grinds well it is not easy to dump all the grinds out. Our old one came with a little brush, which was handy to get the corners. The removable cup is helpful to dump the grounds out. There is also a minimum amount of beans to pour in & unfortunately it will throw the grinds around the cap if not. Sometimes ya just dont need that much coffee...I thought because it was a Kitchen Aid, yah know it would be awesome.

I ordered this coffee grinder to replace my 20 year old moulinex regal which finally croaked. I am so far very satisfied with the purchase. The Kitchen Aid has a larger capacity so you can grind enough coffee for several cups. It appears to be well built and grinds the beans finely as I like. My only two criticisms are it takes a little longer to grind, about 15-20 seconds vs. about 10 seconds for old moulinex regal. Secondly some of the grind ends up below the blades and it takes some effort to get it out. Also these bottom grinds are a little courser than the top. I just hope it is as durable as the moulinex regal.

We bought this blade grinder because our old one, also a KitchenAid, died the good death after about 8 years. I figured anything that lasted that long with no issues would be worth replacing with the same brand. I like the design of this, how little room it takes up, but the grind is just a little finer than I am used to and there is a small amount of "sludge" at the bottom of our french press coffee that wasn't there before. Maybe we're still trying to get the timing right on the grind, but the old one didn't grind as fine as fast. Still happy with it, it's a great grinder for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excited for deal, no small insert for spices
reviews.reviewText:
I got this as a lightening deal and Im generally pleased with it. However, when I bought it, it was not clear it didnt come with the insert for grinding spices. That insert is almost as much as the grinder itself last I checked, and I had hoped it was included. As it is, you have to put in about a third of a cup of beans to get a good grind. It also does heat the beans a little as it goes but that is to be expected.
However, for what it is it works great. I switched to whole bean coffee about two months ago and havent looked back.

coffee grounds get flung everywhere and make a huge mess. the lid doesn't do anything to keep the grinds in. Also the edges of the bowl are very rough which causes the grinds to stick to the bowl. I have to tap it against the counter pretty hard to get everything out. Also a pain in the butt to clean. I feel like they could have used a less rough-textured metal like smooth stainless steel.

Love it, so far. Coming from a Krups that got lost in a move. This is a big step up. The bottom basket can be removed for easy cleaning; a great feature! Compared to the Krups, it also oscillates and lifts the contents more, creating a more even grind, and allows me to get a nice course grind for the French Press. Also, noticeably more quiet than a couple other basic blade grinders I've used. Highly recommend! As always, I will update if anything changes.

Came across this particular coffee grinder when we rented a house on one our trips. Although we had a very good coffee grinder, this one was so superior, I went ahead and ordered one for home. It is slightly larger than most grinders, has a larger motor and grinds twice as much coffee at one time. You can obtain seperately a smaller grinding bowl that one might use for herbs and spices. We are very happy with the product,

Does it work: Yes
Is it loud: Nope

So why don't I like it?
The cup where your pore the beans is too narrow.
The ground beans stick to the tall, narrow cup.
The ground beans get all over the bottom rim of the black part after grinding (very messy).
There is no timed amount it grinds. It just keep going and going.
It has a very long cord.

I don't like it. You might like it if you don't mind making a mess every time you grind coffee.
I tossed this thing in the trash. What a waste of time.

reviews.reviewTitle: KitchenAid BCG111B Coffee Grinder very bad Review
reviews.reviewText: The good...Very nice design & low decibel level operation, hence the 2 stars....the bad...it perfectly fine grinds 1/2 whole coffee beans other half barely grounded coffee beans...very disappointed with this products coffee grinding performance.... I cannot n good conscience recommend KitchenAid in the coffee grinding business... Sorry

Bought this based on other Amazon reviews and love the way it works. Easy to clean (which I was dreading) and there is a manual inside that shows you how long to grind based on how fine or coarse you want your coffee. We bought this for our French Press and the chart was dead accurate which saved some wasted coffee beans. Bought the dark brown color because it was a few dollars cheaper than the other options and it has a rich, expensive appearance that my wife and I both love. Buy this product if you need a coffee bean grinder - I can't imagine how they could have made it any better.

This grinder does what it says. No special settings for fine ground, or anything, just put in beans, press lid, watch/check until coarseness you prefer. Well worth the price
Bad if grinding other than coffee, for those 'green states' there is an 1/8th inch gap under blades, where you have to remove canister, knock that bit of coffee loose. But 5 ? basic, sturdy, easy to use grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quick and efficient for grinding dry dog food! No joke!
reviews.reviewText: We use our coffee grinder to grind individual batches of dry dog food. We have a Border Collie who eats too darn fast and we've been advised to blend her food into a fine powder and mix with warm water. This is our third KitchenAid grinder. Each previous grinder having lasted over a year apiece. By far, this latest model has been grinding her dry food into a powder in probably half of the time it took the older ones. Whatever they changed about their grinders -- WE LOVE IT! We also appreciate the stainless steel appearance and the overall ease of use!

I only purchased this grinder because my old, cheap brand one cracked in the dishwasher. After having that happen, I was delighted to see the stainless steel grinding cup on this one. Honestly, that's the only reason I bought it. I'm done with the plastic grinding cup.

So, I was pleasantly surprised by the size of this one. I grind coffee for the week all at once. With my old, average-sized grinder, it took close to 15 minutes to fill my canister. This one takes less than five. 4 grinds and I am set for the week. MAJOR plus!

I'm giving it five stars, but if it dies on me anytime soon, I'll update. As of now, I love it!

PS - It works best if you only fill it to the "10 Cup" mark. Beyond that, the grind isn't uniform. But that's no biggie.

Outstanding coffee grinder. I purchased this from Amazon after price comparing with local retail stores. I saved right at $10 by purchasing here. As for the grinder, it grinds well. I specifically purchased this model because of the removable cup. I grind coffee beans and dried peppers, and the removable cup allows me to clean effectively after peppers. Additionally, the stainless steel cup doesn't absorb any of the pepper oils. Overall, this grinder looks great and works even better. If I had to gripe about anything, some of my pepper milling allowed small particles to bypass the lid and get on the outside of the cup. This was easily cleaned up and wasn't a big deal in the end. I would definitely recommend or purchase this product again.

I bought this grinder after my old Hamilton Beach bit the dust. Surprisingly, my 10-year old grinder worked much better than this one. KitchenAid's grinder results in very uneven coffee grounds. If you don't want some chunks and some espresso grounds, you have to stop the grinder, "unpack" the coffee that's trapped underneath the blades and blend again. A lot of fine coffee grounds get compacted in the bottom of the grinder. There is usually residue in my brewed cup, even though there are also beans that are barely chopped. Very uneven.

My husband and I love fresh-ground coffee, but after going through 3 electric grinders we decided to do our research before purchasing this grinder. This is the only grinder we found that is completely stainless steel on the inside - NO PLASTIC comes in contact with our beans now! It took us a couple of times experimenting with this one to see how much/long to allow the beans to grind. We found we like to grind them in short bursts, say 7 seconds, 5 and 5. At that point the beans are ground to our specification and our coffee comes out perfectly. The grounds do get stuck in the bottom but that is nothing a little shaking of the removable stainless steel cup won't fix. All our grounds come out of the cup each time with nothing left but a little dust. Can't say enough good things about this grinder!!

The depth of the grinder part is really great and fits a lot of coffee however, The blades are higher than my old ones and I am constantly having to scrap coffee off the bottom of this one. I grind coffee at 330 am and this one is much louder and sounds a lot worse than my former grinder. Im surprised, it does a good job grinding but does sound on its last leg.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't recommend, look for something better
reviews.reviewText: Pretty terrible grinder, only good for a coarse grind (fine for french press) but definitely not good for AeroPress use. That's all fine, but the worst part is that the coffee grind easily escapes over the container and underneath the cover. Coffee grinds end up all over the edges, under the container, and of course all over your counter. Major design flaw.

I searched long and hard for an all-stainless-steel coffee grinder. Most grinders have seams that collect old coffee grinds and dust, always needing for you to dig it out with a sharp object. I wanted a smooth, steel grinder bowl with no seams. This is that coffee grinder! But it has an added bonus I never expected to find: the grinder bowl is removable! Take it out and load it up anywhere, leaving the motorized base where it sits, plugged into the electric socket. No longer do you have to move the grinder out from the wall, drag the cord across whatever is on your cabinet or stove, handle it and put it back when you are done. Instead, just remove the bowl with a simple twist, place it wherever is convenient to measure your coffee, then place it back in the base to grind the coffee. When done, you don't have to pick up the grinder to pour the coffee into the coffeepot. Just remove the bowl again. It empties so easily, and because it's a single piece of stainless steel without seams, the coffee all comes out easily. I use a barista brush to dust out under the blades, though a light whack on the side of the steel cup, like a cowbell, will usually do the trick with no need for further brushing.

My first one wore out after about 5 years. I'm on my 2nd one now, and I've bought one for each of my kids, as well as my grandmother, who still loves a cup of joe at her age of 100+. Highly recommended!

reviews.reviewTitle: For the price, it can't be beat.
reviews.reviewText: Does what it says. For the price, it can't be beat. Only complaint might be, that you really can't do a coarse grind with this. That doesn't bother me as I prefer finely ground coffee, but could be bothersome to some folks. I filled it to the max with bean and it did a good job at grinding them all. Not near as bad as other cheap grinders, but still requires a little tilting/tapping to get a complete grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Design allows coffee grounds to escape grind cup.
reviews.reviewText:
Well-built. Motor is very strong. Nice that the grinding cup is removable for cleaning and brushing out coffee grounds.

My only complaint is that there is enough of a gap between the outer cover and the grind cup that coffee ground gets out of the grind cup and gets into the space between the cup and the lower unit. Otherwise, no other complaints.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's easy to clean (we hand wash this) and the unit ...
reviews.reviewText: Go figure - I sold my MagicBullet last month and then bough coffee thinking it was already ground, but it was the whole bean! So I needed to buy a grinder for the beans. Reviews for this product were solid, so I went for it. We've only used coffee beans in it a few times, but it grinds well and is surprisingly quiet (WAY quieter than the MagicBullet was!!). It's easy to clean (we hand wash this) and the unit is smaller than I anticipated, so it fits under the cabinet easily. Really happy with this purchase.

This is a good quality, quiet grinder. I had a Braun before this one and the blade didn't last very long. This one has a good, hard stainless blade that chops the beans up pretty good plus the grinder looks good. I only gave it 4 stars though because I thougt it could use a little improvement on it's ability to move the beans around more whenever you really fill it. When you fill the grinding chamber close to the top, the beans do not move. This may be due to the weight of the beans and the blade being only a straight piece of metal instead of having a shape somewhat like an airplane propellor which would help move the beans around. I ended up tilting the grinder in order for the beans to move down to the blade. There is no problem when you fill the chamber only 3/4 full.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well for a medium grind.
reviews.reviewText: This product I feel is easy to use and you can easily empty the grounds from this to another contain. I could not get to a fine of ground as I wanted even when griding for an extended period, but I like really finely ground coffee. While if you do fill the grinder to full some grinds become for ground then others in the same group. This can happen even if not using the maximum amount allowed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Strong motor so I gave it 3 stars.
reviews.reviewText: One major flaw with this grinder... The grinder blades are both turned up. So instead of one side grinding below and one side grinding anything above, both sides grind everything above the blades and anything that falls underneath just lays there. It takes much longer to grind with this one than it did with my Epica Electric Coffee Grinder. This grinder is like your standard blender, it'll get the job done with a little extra effort. The Epica is like using a Ninja. Go check that one out. The over under blades makes it the better buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worthy of the brand name
reviews.reviewText: Grinding cup is not intuitive to install or remove. Users struggle getting it in the base and into proper alignment for grinding. After a bit of use, cup began to stick in lock position so that removal is now problematic. Users tend to leave cup installed rather than fight with it, which defeats easy cleaning potential. Noise level is average.

This is the 2nd one I've purchased-I've had one for some time and I also got one for my daughter. It stays sharp and does a good job of grinding. It is easy to use-much more so than other grinders I've owned in the past. Being stainless, it's easy to clean the outside. The grounds release pretty easily from the inside so it doesn't require much cleaning, basically wipe with a dry cloth if needed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perhaps what's best about this grinder is it's ability to be washed ...
reviews.reviewText:
Perhaps what's best about this grinder is it's ability to be washed after each use. This makes it a very useful tool in the kitchen as it doubles as a spice grinder without the need to "clear" the bowl by grinding rice or bread. I knocked off a star because the decorative front piece came off and serves no purpose other than decoration. Also, it is very loud and difficult to hear when the grind is finished.

By the way, I noticed the grinder in use on a Rick Bayless video for making mole.

Works excellently for the price and is able to grind the beans pretty perfectly. You do have to shake it up or stir once while using it or you will have unground beans (not many) towards the top. This product is working great for me though. I have a friend that I noticed had one of these and I asked him how he liked his. He's had his for over 5 years and has no plans on replacing it because it was super cheap and has worked consistently for years. Sounds like I made a great buy!

Works well. Some people have complained that the grind is somewhat uneven. I agree with that but I get really good coffee so I don't care if a few of the beans don't get ground. I like that the grinding bowl is removable for cleaning. It is quieter and easier to clean than the Mr. Coffee grinder it replaced. Takes longer to grind than the Mr. Coffee did. Like 20 seconds instead of 10. A lot of grounds remain in the grinding bowl that have to be brushed out instead of dumping out into the brewer basket. All in all, though, much happier with it than the Mr. Coffee grinder that was really loud and a pain to clean as the grinding bowl was not removable for cleaning on the Mr. Coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This machine doesn't exactly grind all of your beans evenly ...
reviews.reviewText: This machine doesn't exactly grind all of your beans evenly. Even when I do as little as 4 cups, I have to stop after a few seconds & scrape the finely ground coffee from under the blade & mix it with the rest of the beans which are still very coarse. I never have gotten all of the beans to grind uniformly. It gets the job done I suppose, hence the second star. I would not purchase again.

I bought this because I grow pumpkins, roast them, dehydrate them, and powder them. Pumpkin powder is a great way to store pumpkin, and rehydrates very easily to the consistency of fresh baked pumpkin. This little gem will grind dried pumpkin like a dream. Nothing else I've tried will come close. I bought a second for my parents, it was so great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Grinder but shipped with a defect in the cord
reviews.reviewText:
I was excited to receive this grinder, a KitchenAid! Considering that this product came from and was Shipped from Amazon, I would have thought there would have been some Quality Control before shipping. I guess, the package is NOT opened prior to shipping for inspection. I did not notice at first that the cord has a double insulation but in one spot the insulation has a cut in it. The 2nd insulation layer is solid, and therefore I will continue using the grinder as it is, but was disappointed that it was shipped with a defect. As for the grinder itself, it does exactly what it is described to do on the KitchenAid website and is quiet and efficient.

http://www.amazon.com/KitchenAid-BCG111ES-Blade-Coffee-Grinder/dp/B00AB6QT44/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?s=kitchen&ie=UTF8&qid=1452269808&sr=1-1-fkmr0&keywords=KitchenAid+BCG111ES+Blade+C

Overall I'm very happy with how well it grinds my coffee beans. My only knock (if any) would be noise level.
Product description led me to believe that this unit is significantly less noisy than other competitive grinders.
However the sound level is pretty much the on the same level of all the other electric grinders that I have had.

reviews.reviewTitle: Okay, but there are better grinders.
reviews.reviewText: It's not terrible, but there are better coffee grinders for the same price. The removable cup is a nice feature. The motor is weak, so it takes forever to grind and can't really grind coffee very finely. Also it's not great for grinding spices since it won't really grind things up unless you put a lot in there. The switch mechanism is also sort of wonky, since you push the whole clear plastic cap down, but sometimes it takes some jiggling to get it to go down.

Quite loud. Does not grind evenly. Youll have powder in the bottom and large chunks mingled in. You can cut your hand trying to remove or install the metal cup that holds the grounds. Also can be a challenge to line up the tiny buttons which allow the machine to operate.

This grinder is easy to use and can easily cleaned for sampling various coffees. I liked it so much I bought another as a gift and have recommended it to others as well. You can grind just what you intend to use right away, and so your coffee is always fresh. The bean bowl is washable too.

This thing is loud as heck and vibrates wildly. The removable bowl does not have any positive feedback that it is completely seated and comes unseated if only trying to grind beans for a few cups of coffee. I don't know how this thing is supposed to work, but if what I experienced is it then don't buy it. This is the first negative review I've ever written. I really can't believe how cheap and crappy this grinder felt. Returning mine immediately.

reviews.reviewTitle: I want to love it, but....
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to grind pepper. It does a decent job. Some is a bit fine and some a bit chunky but the biggest problem is that it throws pepper all over the inside of the grinder. I realize this is a coffee grinder but I dont drink coffee so I dont know whether that would be an issue with coffee or not.

Noisy, wobbly, and the lid doesn't keep anything in. Ended up with bits of things I was grinding down in the base of the unit where the motor is, they would fly up to the top, go over the edge of the work bowl, and then fall down the sides. Poor blade contact, couldn't get a fine grind on anything I tried it with, even after purchasing the smaller 'spice grinder' bowls.

I bought this to replace my trusty Braun. This is now on the shelf and the Braun is back in use. There are good things, like the removable grinding canister. But the problem is the stupid thing leaks. Here is the deal, the round grinding container does not force or circulate the coffee like the oblong Braun does. So, you have to shake this unit while it grinds. Fin. But, for some silly reason, there is a small gap between the top of the grinding canister and the lid and when you shake, to get a good grind, the already-ground coffe goes out through that gap and into the base of the grinder. Booooo. Bad design, KitchenAid, bad design.

reviews.reviewTitle: Sharp looking. Works great. Easy to use and clean.
reviews.reviewText: Arrived on time and well packaged. Brand new condition. Works great. Easy to use and easy to clean. Looks sharp and doesnt take up inch space. Fully happy with this purchase. Would but again and would recommend.
I bought 2 of these, it worked well for coffee beans but was a disaster for spices. A thin dust went all over inside and out of the grinder, I did not finish grinding due to the mess.

My old Hamilton Beach Custom Grind finally bit the dust after years of use - loved this unit. With Kitchen Aid's reputation I thought what the heck, give it a try. It's not that the Kitchen Aid doesn't work, it does - but just 'eh' is my opinion. It clumps the coffee together and gathers at the bottom. It does not grind the coffee as fine as my old one no mater how long you hold the lid down. Not my favorite coffee grinder by a long shot & not near as nice as my old one. Took it out of the box, used it so I will keep it. I will say the color is very attractive but I cannot honestly say I recommend it.

Just purchased the KitchenAid factory refurbished on ebay for $20 including shipping. Besides a stylish stainless steel exterior it has 2 important advantages over my deceased Mr. Coffee and my now back up Capresso grinders.

1. It has a twist out container with handy markings for measuring your coffee grinds without the annoying plastic cage you find inside the Mr. Coffee grinder. It's much easier to clean after each use using a recommended brush. It also looks great in my kitchen sitting on a grayish corian counter top next to my stainless steel toaster!

2. It's quieter than either the Mr. Coffee and Capresso grinders and the instruction manual provides handy timing suggestions. For example it recommends holding down the grinder 17 seconds for an 8 cup or 13 seconds for a 4 cup grind.

Item as described by seller. Product is easy to use. However, coffee grains pop out all over the place and it gets very very messy. I had to keep this product inside the large sandwich bag each time of grinding to prevent from grains popping out from the grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: great grinder for all my needs
reviews.reviewText: I've only had it for a few months, but it seems to do a great job for the price. I sometimes grind my beans up fine for drip or french press and other times coarse for cold brew. You can control the duration and pulsing of the grind pretty easily. Easy to clean... I literally just rinse it and maybe use a little soap and can't see any residues collecting as far as I can tell (not too worried anyway cause it's just coffee...). Like others have said, don't fill up more than 1/2 or 3/4 full and you'll be fine - there is no reason to, you can grind in batches. unless you're making like 10 cups of coffee every morning this should not slow you down a bit.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bad design! Spend a little more if you want to use daily.
reviews.reviewText: Sadly, the notches on the lid did not fit well into the base. To turn on the grinder, they must lock in place- so heres my issue. I could hardly get this grinder to work! Not to mention the metal cup basically bent in my small hand when I tried to twist it into the base. My guess is just overall cheap manufacturing/material. Too bad! Had to return.

This unit is about 17 months old now and works like a champ. What I like about it is that the lid never gets dirty and the can is big enough for a stout 12 cups of coffee. I do have a small spoon use to loosen up the ground coffee in the very bottom of the grinder that seems to like to not come out when you pour the coffee into the maker basket. Here is hoping for another 10 years of use!

reviews.reviewTitle: This thing is highly overrated. In order to get ...
reviews.reviewText: This thing is highly overrated. In order to get all the whole beans ground up (even coarsely) you need to run it until the bottom half of the coffee is packed into the bottom of the cup and difficult to remove. Thankfully the cup is removable, or this shortcoming would convince me to return it. I have owned several inexpensive KRUPS grinders that outperform this thing at a third of the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does the job, but I bought this so ...
reviews.reviewText: It does the job, but I bought this so all the grounds would stay in the cup and not make a mess. I don't know why it was designed this way, but grounds come out over the top and drop down along the rim and under the cup getting grounds everywhere still. To me a simple fix would be a lid on top of the cup. I will say it is slightly less messy than the one I had before that ground everything in the top cap.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome! First time I have ever ground my own beans
reviews.reviewText:
It is of such fine quality and workmanship. I wish it had settings as to what grind it is doing, but I am sure I will get the hang of it.
I bought it so I could brew my coffee in my Keurig Hot 2.0 with beans I grind myself.
As described, there are markings on the inside of the cup so you know how much to put in.
I like the idea that if you don't press, it does not run. A good safety feature.

Its difficult to clean and when Im using it I want all the coffee grinds or marijuana to pour out but the blades hold it down preventing any easy clean pour, it makes it very messy and I lose product everytime .

I have owned this for a few years ago and have used it to grind some pretty solid material. The mechanism is still very stable and runs just like how it did when I bought it. I recommend adding the spice grinder attachment for fresh black pepper and herbs

It does grind easy & its easy to clean its nice and big inside to grind your coffee grounds or herbs grind. I am hoping motor last. Its better than the Cruisinart we had before it died. Its not loud at all and Im so happy with this grinder. We been using this grinder since January and so far it is awesome & we love it. Craftsmanship and durability is 100 % Awesome. Thanks Will buy again from this company.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent deal works well but wont brew your coffee for you
reviews.reviewText: There isnt really much to say about KitchenAid that hasnt already been said. I gave it 5 stars because it does the job every time, push down and ground beans happen. Theres some oddball chunks here and there if you dont really give it enough time but it's quiet for a grinder and works every time I need it to so far.

This coffee grinder is not very good. Loud, hard to use - hard to get the cup back in place to grind for the next time. The grinds end up in the bottom section. Hard to get the cover back on & aligned correctly. Disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: DANGEROUS MACHINE : NEEDS TO BE RECALLED
reviews.reviewText: When one removes the tub that the beans to go in you may cut your hands. The top edge is sharp. DONT buy this piece of crap. I have cut myself twice taking out this tub to clean it and I have rough tough Electrican hands.

works well. Some have complained of the mass when grinding. I have found that only occurs when trying to do only enough beans for one cup of coffee. As long as one puts enough beans in up to the minimum line ( enough for 4 cups) , there's little if any mess.

reviews.reviewTitle: The coffee grinder to beat all others.
reviews.reviewText: Over the years I have had many styles of coffee grinders. But the mess they make had me putting away my whole beans for pre-ground coffee. KitchenAid has solved the problem of static electricity that is a problem with other grinders. The grinder cup is metal. It nests on a grinder base that moves the blade located in the metal cup. Similar to a blender base. Than you give a little twist to the cup which releases it, and put the grounds in your coffee maker. There are graduated marks on the cup. I tried the 12 cup mark and it was stout coffee, even for me. So now I just use me coffee scoop and put six spoonfuls of beans in the cup. It is also quieter than any other grinders I have owned. You wont be disappointed if you purchase this. Happy grinding.

My first coffee grinder. Does what it is designed to do. Its not that loud. It grinds coffee beans just like the description says.Maybe I am, to simple, as a person but it is a coffee grinder and it grinds coffee.Best coffee grinder ever. Unless it burns your house down or electrocutes you, why you would give a product that does what it is designed to do anything less than 5 stars.

Bought this for my wife who is of Latin persuasion and very particular. It was everything I hoped it would be. Well built, dependable, versatile,
in that she has no issues with out of the U.S. grown beans etc. I would definately recommend this item. Thanks Amazon

I've owned two of these over the last decade and only had to replace my last one because it was lost during moving. I've never had any trouble with the motor and the have used it to make course grinds for french press as well as more fine grinds for pour over. Nice, reliable, economical grinder for everyday use.

As all KitchenAid products do, this one works GREAT! Built sturdily, it does what it's supposed,
a tad noisy, but one can't avoid that with a coffee bean grinder. I LOVE ALL my KitchenAid
products!

I like the chop with this coffee grinder. Also, it is easy to clean since the section with the blade can be separated from the main unit. Have had one of these for many years and it's the best coffee grinder I've owned.

Worked really well for 4 months then suddenly would no longer turn on or do anything. We used it once a day to grind coffee for 2 people and left it sitting on the counter. That's all it had to do and it couldn't hold up. Thought we we were getting a good one. Very disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not good to powder herbs or spices
reviews.reviewText: I like that I can take the stainless steel cup out of the grinder to clean. HOWEVER, most of the powder from grinding is everywhere EXCEPT the cup. Might work well with coffee beans but for other grinding use a different grinder.

I use this to grind spices. It does an excellent job. Although, the grind is not overall even. I appreciate the turn and lift out cup. It's easy to wash. It's small and easy to store. It feels sturdy. I hope to have it for a long time.

reviews.reviewTitle: I loved the grinder itself if you are looking for a ...
reviews.reviewText: I loved the grinder itself if you are looking for a no frills, simple coffee grinder. There are plenty more for very specific measuring and types of course-ness, but this is just a push it and done grinder. Works great. Had a bit of trouble getting the cup out of the main machine to be able to clean it, but after a few uses got a bit easier.

First off - coffee grinder should be grinding coffee, but it does not! I bought this because I wanted a bowl separate which can be washed in dishwasher. But apparently the design does not work at all. While grinding coffee most of the coffee flies outside the lid. so when you open the lid everything is spilled and above all the coffee is not even fine ground! Not worth at all. I wanted to return it but I do not have original box anymore and so I am stuck it with now.

Works fine but the blade sits pretty high, so the grounds on the bottom end up with different consistency than the rest and get stuck down there. The better designed grinders seem to have a blade that sits lower, resulting in better consistency. Grounds in the bottom always get stuck.

reviews.reviewTitle: I do not recommend this product
reviews.reviewText:
I do not recommend this product. I needed a spice grinder and thought this would be perfect. I loved the design and colors.
well, when you turn it on it shoots up your spices. up and out of the metal "cup" and gets on the plastic lid.
It's messy. inconvenient. And it seemed to me like the motor is not even that strong.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well for French press coffee
reviews.reviewText: I think if you drink espresso, where it matters how uniform the grind is, you need a grinder that will uniformly grind the beans. We use French press, and I used to think it mattered whether the grounds were uniform or not, but the hot water sits in the carafe for 4 minutes, so if some of the grounds are slightly smaller or larger than others, the flavors will still get extracted. I've concluded uniformity is not necessary in this case. Why spend the money for a burr grinder if you don't need to?

I love this grinder!! I have used the The Mr. Coffee, Krups, and Cuisinart coffee grinders and this hands down the best one. The KitchenAid grinder is well built, unlike Mr. Coffee, has measuring lines indicating for up to 12 cups of coffee, unlike Krups which has no lines and a smaller capacity.This grinder is also shaped well and easy to hold, unlike the square Cuisinart Grinder. This grinder is going to last a very long time because it is well constructed. The cord is also very sturdy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Look around and if you dont like it return it right away!
reviews.reviewText: Its okay, I really loved my old one but it finally stopped working so I bought this one. Its bulky I havent figured out how many beans to grind for the amount of coffee I want. Ill learn just sayin this is not bad but its not great either, maybe Ill get use to it.??
Love this coffee grinder. Does the job, easy to use and I especially appreciate that the cup can be removed! No messy coffee grinds all over the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really like this grinder but worried about durability
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to wait to provide decent info on this product. Very happy with this grinder initially. There is a plastic insert which consists of a few blades which allows for the user to turn and scrape inside of grinder to loosen fresh grounds stuck to internal walls. Recently these blades broke free and the obvious noise, while in use, alerted me to stop using the grinder. I readjusted these blades and the noise went away. I am concerned how much longer these blades will remain in place. Owned this item for less than a year. So far so good after the readjustment.

Despite having a fairly powerful motor, this grinder yields a very uneven grind of beans and is very unsuitable for French press. Grounds will scatter along the inner rim underneath the lid, causing a bit of a mess every use.

I had high hopes for this unit. One morning I go to use it and it does not work. I can hear the click when you push the lid, but nothing happens. I checked the cord, electric, and even removed the motor to see if grinds were stuck by the connector. Nothing. No wires were disconnected in the motor and a friend of mine who favors electronics said that the motor has an issue. I did not save the box so I have no idea how I would return it.

I am not a heavy coffee grinder, I dont need a fancy coffee grinder.So this works for me, there was a learning curve on how long to hold it down for, but it was easy to figure it out. Washing it was simple, it comes apart to wash. It is heavy and feels well built. I really like it and think it would work for anyone

I bought one of these coffee grinders a few years ago, (January 2011 according to Amazon) use it daily, love it and wanted to see if it was still available, just in case I need another. I don't need another as the one I have works as well as it did the day I got it. It is reliable, well worth the price and I recommend this coffee grinder without exception.

...ideal for coffee especially if you're using a Keurig, way to fine of a grind and no way to adjust it. Guess I've come to expect a lot from KitchenAid and this time they really didn't come through...

Extremely helpful!
I love to drink coffee every day, so having a machine like this to grind the beans whenever I am not in a rush is perfect!

When used correctly, this coffee grinder works wonders! It is very easy to use and produces the expected results. It can even grind dried herbs, which is is especially useful when cooking meals that require a specific amount of herbs to not overpower with taste.

I bought this to go with the new coffeemaker I purchased for my husband's birthday. This seemed the best choice after reading quite a few reviews on many other products. Also, I had used this same grinder at my son's house, and they have never had a problem with it's operation. It grinds the coffee evenly and the grounds don't stick to the stainless steel mill or the top. What's not to like?!

DO NOT BUY.

The blade design means heaver bits get caught underneath, so you can't easily grind cinnamon sticks, star anise, or any kind of dried chili into anything resembling a powder, nor is it powerful enough to do anything other then toss it around the cup.

The poor design means that if you're eventually grinding something to a powder, it will get everywhere, it will escape the main vessel and end up pooling underneath it near/on the drive wheel.

I'm a coffee lover and this grinders does it's job just right.
It turns the beans well around, the result is just fantastic and smells great as it was grinned on a stone mill.
I've had so many grinders and now I finally discovered the right one.

The grinder doesn't grind coffee in a uniform manner at all. If you shake it to get the beans to grind more evenly while grinding, the coffee gets between the cover and the metal vessel that holds the beans, and when you take the cover off it makes a huge mess. I have to grind the coffee, pause, stir it around in the grinder with a butter knife, then grind again, and still there is some coffee that is powdery with chunks mixed it. This might be good for spices because you can clean it, but don't expect an even grind. I wouldn't recommend buying this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: KitchenAid Missed the Mark On This One
reviews.reviewText: Very unimpressed with KitchenAid this time! The coffee grounds become compacted underneath the blade. You have to use a small spoon to dig the coffee grounds out. I very unhappy with this purchase.

This coffee grinder has three great things going for it: 1) the coffee compartment is huge so you can grind up lots of coffee; 2) the coffee compartment is removal so you can get the ground coffee out easily without turning the entire appliance upside down; and 3) the grinder is very quiet compared to other coffee grinders I have used in the past, so you can use it without waking everyone. Overall I am very satisfied.

The only down sides are that the cord does not retract or store out of sight, and there is only one setting for the grinder, so there is little control over how fine or course you grind the coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very NICELY DESIGNED, but unfortunately the grindr is VERY WEAK ...
reviews.reviewText:
Very NICELY DESIGNED, but unfortunately the grindr is VERY WEAK which turns grinding coffee into a hassle each time. The result is always a VERY COARSE POWER with some few entire or half coffee beans inbetween. The powder sits in the grinding container and you have to use a spoon to turn the powder to achieve a good result.

I would like to return it, and would not recommend buying it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Plastic on cup part damaged after 1 year
reviews.reviewText: I liked this grinder a lot because of the stainless steel cup. It worked great for a year, then the bottom of the cup, which is plastic, became damaged. It now has a couple of 1" wide holes in the plastic at the base. Perhaps due to the constant reverberation of the motor? It still works, sort of. I'm giving this 2 *s because the part I thought I could rely on, the stainless steel cup, has a bottom plastic issue. I tried to get the part on the Kitchenaid site and listed the model #, but apparently they don't carry it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder without too much noise
reviews.reviewText: This sucker really grinds. Does a great job. Can grind enough for a full 12 cup pot and grinds evenly and thoroughly while being fairly quiet. It does not wake the house up when I grind. I got this because the burr grinder is SO LOUD IT IS @)#(#*&#. I will say the burr makes coffee taste better, but this grinder does a fine job.

Amazing little grinder. Quality material and easy to use and clean. I only use it about once a week but it could definitely withstand more frequent use. The slim design makes storage a breeze. Very happy with this purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: So I hear KitchenAid makes great products...
reviews.reviewText: ...and they do! This product is Exactly what I wanted. It's big and powerful and a huge upgrade over the old hamilton beach that died after 8 years of faithful service. The biggest plus is being able to remove and wash the stainless cup and blades. I love this coffee grinder so much I'll shop the brand much more often.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works for the use of grinding coffee beans
reviews.reviewText: This simple yet efficient machine is great for a small amount of coffee beans. Its sleek design can be left on counter net to my Kitchen aide coffee maker, without being obtrusive.

This grinder is faster than others I've had in the past. I just wish I could have found one with grind settings. It definitely grinds quite fine.
I love the removal and washable stainless steel cup. My old grinder didn't have a removable cup, making cleaning difficult.
When I grind the coffee, some of the grounds overflows into the track that holds the cup in place. The grounds in the track makes it difficult to unscrew the cup. It grinds coffee to my satisfaction.
larger capacity than the cuisinart blade grinder, easy to lift off grounds unit makes transfer into coffee maker or storage bin easier and cleaner.

The coffee escapes over the grinder bin while you're grinding and makes a horrible mess *ever* time. I've never seen any other grinder with this problem.

Judging from some of the reviews this isn't a problem for all units thus it's clear the quality control is crap. I recommend steering clear.
